patient_context:
I feel anxious and avoid going back to the animal shelter because I believe the animals there will hate me for not remembering me. This leads to feelings of guilt and self-blame.
These feelings started a few months ago after a visit to the shelter where some animals did not greet me as warmly as before.
I believe the stress level when this problem started was moderate, as I tend to internalize situations related to animals.
The problem has escalated over time, causing me to avoid the shelter altogether. The fear of being rejected by the animals has grown stronger.
I experience these negative thoughts and emotions whenever I think about returning to the animal shelter.
I have tried to challenge these thoughts on my own but have been unsuccessful in changing my beliefs.

I decided to seek counseling because this issue has started affecting my daily life and my passion for working with animals.

I have not experienced similar problems before.
I have not received treatment or counseling for psychological problems in the past.
I do not have any significant physical illnesses.

My job performance as a veterinary assistant has not been affected yet, but my passion for working with animals has dwindled.
Interpersonal relationships: My relationships with other animal shelter volunteers have been strained as I have distanced myself because of this issue.
Daily life: My anxiety about going to the shelter has disrupted my sleep patterns and overall well-being.

I have a few close friends who are supportive, but they do not fully understand the extent of my anxiety related to the animal shelter.
core_beliefs: black-and-white or polarized thinking / all or nothing thinking
intermediate_beliefs: Animals will reject me if I return to the shelter because they remember that I didn't give them enough attention, and I will be seen as untrustworthy and unworthy of their affection.
automatic_thoughts: I frequent this animal shelter. All of the animals remembered me except a few, I can never go back there again they will hate me

patient_context:
I feel that people will always think I am weird because of my interest in crystals, which leads to feelings of isolation and loneliness.
These feelings started a few years ago when I started delving deeper into the powers of crystals.
The stress level when these feelings first occurred was moderate, as I received some negative comments from acquaintances about my interest.
The problem has progressed over time, especially after I heard more negative remarks from people about my crystal collection.
I experience these feelings regularly, especially when discussing my interests with others or receiving judgmental comments.
I have tried to ignore the negative remarks and focus on my passion for crystals, but the comments still affect me.

The increasing feelings of isolation and loneliness made me realize the need to seek counseling to address these negative thoughts and emotions.

I have not experienced similar problems before.
I have not received treatment or counseling for psychological problems in the past.
I do not have any significant physical illnesses.

My job performance as a seamstress has been satisfactory, but my interpersonal relationships have been affected.
Interpersonal relationships: My relationships with acquaintances and friends have been strained due to their judgment of my interests.
Daily life: My interest in crystals is a big part of my daily routine, from using them for meditation to decorating my space with them.

I have a few friends I can talk to about general topics, but I do not feel comfortable discussing my feelings of isolation and judgment with them.
intermediate_beliefs: If I express my interest in crystals, people will judge me as weird, so I should avoid discussing it to prevent rejection.
automatic_thoughts: I'm really into my crystals. People will probably always think I am weird.

patient_context:
I have 8 brothers, and despite being close, we don't live near each other. The thought of never seeing them again causes me great anxiety and distress.
These feelings and thoughts started recently when the pandemic restrictions limited travel and family gatherings.
The stress level increased significantly during the pandemic when travel became restricted, and I couldn't see my brothers as often as before.
The problem has progressed to the point where I constantly worry about losing touch with my brothers and never being able to reunite.
I experience these thoughts and fears almost daily, especially when I see news about the pandemic or travel restrictions.
I have tried to distract myself with hobbies and activities, but the worries always come back.

The fear and anxiety about losing touch with my brothers have become overwhelming, leading me to seek counseling for support and guidance in managing these thoughts.

I have not experienced similar problems before.
I have not received treatment or counseling for psychological problems in the past.
I do not have any significant physical illnesses.

Not specified
Interpersonal relationships: My relationships with my brothers have been affected by my constant worries and fears of losing touch.
Daily life: My anxiety about losing touch with my brothers has impacted my daily activities and focus.

I have 8 brothers whom I am close to, but discussing my fears and anxieties with them directly feels overwhelming.
core_beliefs: black-and-white or polarized thinking / all or nothing thinking
situation: I have 8 brothers and we are close, but we don't live near each other. I am afraid I'll never see them again.
intermediate_beliefs: Losing touch with my brothers means I will never be able to reconnect with them, and our relationship will be completely lost forever.
automatic_thoughts: I have 8 brothers and while we are close, we don't live near each other. I'm afraid I'll never see them again.

patient_context:
I often feel like everyone in the world thinks I'm a loser and that I'll never amount to anything. These thoughts have led to feelings of worthlessness and low motivation.
These feelings started during my teenage years and have persisted into adulthood.
It started when I was often called a slacker and a weirdo for my appearance and interests.
The problem has worsened over time, especially after facing rejection in relationships and struggles to find stable employment.
I experience these feelings regularly, particularly in social situations or when facing new challenges.
I have tried to counter these thoughts with positive thinking and self-affirmations but have not seen much improvement.

I decided to seek counseling because these negative thoughts have been impacting my daily life, relationships, and overall well-being.

I have experienced similar feelings of worthlessness and low self-esteem in the past.
I have not received treatment or counseling for psychological issues before.
I do not have any significant physical illnesses.

My job performance has been inconsistent due to my lack of motivation.
Interpersonal relationships: I struggle to form and maintain relationships due to my negative self-perception.
Daily life: My self-esteem issues have affected my self-care routines and overall well-being.

I do not have a strong social support system and often feel isolated in dealing with my problems.
situation: I believe that everyone in the world thinks I am a loser and that I will never amount to anything.
automatic_thoughts: Everyone in the world probably thinks I'm a loser.  I will never amount to anything.

patient_context:
I feel that if I don’t find friends, my life will be a waste, leading to feelings of loneliness and despair.
These feelings of loneliness started a few years ago when I moved to a new city for work.
I believe the cause of this issue is my introverted nature and difficulty in socializing.
The problem has been persistent and worsened over time as I struggle to form connections with others.
I experience these feelings almost daily, especially when I see others socializing or attending social events.
I have tried joining clubs and socializing more at work, but I still feel lonely and disconnected.

The persistent feelings of loneliness and despair have begun to affect my mental health and overall well-being, prompting me to seek counseling.

I have experienced similar feelings of loneliness and despair before, especially during times of significant life changes.
I have not received any treatment or counseling for psychological problems in the past.
I do not have any significant physical illnesses.

My job performance has not been impacted significantly by my feelings of loneliness.
Interpersonal relationships: I have a good relationship with my colleagues at work, but I struggle to form deeper connections with them.
Daily life: My feelings of loneliness have affected my motivation to engage in self-care activities and pursue hobbies.

My only friend and source of support is my pet dog. I do not have close relationships with humans that I feel comfortable discussing my feelings of loneliness with.
core_beliefs: black-and-white or polarized thinking / all or nothing thinking
situation: I do not currently have friends. I believe that without friends, my life will be meaningless. I am convinced that my situation is worse than it actually is and that I am unable to make any positive changes. I focus only on the negative aspects of my life and assume that this pattern will continue indefinitely. I believe that my lack of friends is solely my fault and that I am completely incapable of forming meaningful relationships.
automatic_thoughts: If I don’t find some friends, my life will be a waste
